[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a dark green
leather captain's chair here.

sit chair
You sit down on a dark green leather captain's chair.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
land
The starship is already moving.
land
Would you like to request landing clearance at New Earth?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You notify flight control of your desire to land.

transponder. You are cleared to land at the city of New Phoenix."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.

2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and request
reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be placed on
stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the way, I would
engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy any
interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of the
enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance space
from all hostile threats.
You entered: I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and

way, I would engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy

3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "Hi."
[General Communication] Morris Corlew transmits, "Yo."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Hi."
 I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily on lasers
that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is able to
recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is depleted, the
ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of being short a
gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can move to the
empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons room's grid is
recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer to apply quick
patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a failsafe or not.
Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can increase the damage
for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for being short a gunner.
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']

6. In the event of a large-scale invasion of human space by hostile forces, what

[Notification from Space Explorers Amidst The Stars] A load of salvage has been

two-person medium transport "Salvage Regent". The organization has earned

My priority would be the capitol planets as they are the most inhabited and also
the primary beacon sectors since they are used the most and one must fly through
those sectors to get to capitol sectors. If, for example, providence Gate were
to be interdicted, other ships would not be able to get to New Earth until such
time that Providence Gate was no longer interdicted.

1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
You entered: I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy
any interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many
ships as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be
reinforced and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My
goal would be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
You entered: I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and
request reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be
placed on stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the
way, I would engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy
any interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of
the enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance
space from all hostile threats.
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
You entered: I attempt to destroy any chaining ships, interdicting ships and any
interdictors in the sector all the while staying close to the edge in order to
make a quick get away. Having taken note of the number of ships remaining in the
sector, I leave, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to determine the
number of the reinforcing ships. I report all of this over tactical and ask for
reinforcements.
5. You are part of a large combat force attacking an Outsider patrol. You easily
overwhelm them, but before you can take out the stragglers, a Magistrate-class
regional mothership appears. What do you and your allies do and why?
You entered: We destroy the escorting ships and leave since this kind of ship
cannot be destroyed by conventional weapons. The last magistrate-class
mothership had to be captured with the use of battle suits. We contact the
Accord and don't come back without cruisers that have been adapted with special
shielding that can repel a PDB and battle suits.
6. In the event of a large-scale invasion of human space by hostile forces, what
would be your priority and why?
You entered: My priority would be the capitol planets as they are the most
inhabited and also the primary beacon sectors since they are used the most and
one must fly through those sectors to get to capitol sectors. If, for example,
providence Gate were to be interdicted, other ships would not be able to get to
New Earth until such time that Providence Gate was no longer interdicted. 
7. In an emergency, you and your ship are placed at the disposal of a naval wing
commander. How do you feel you would handle this situation?
You entered: I would simply obey the naval wing commander within reason. I would
first ensure that I understood everything he or she asked of me and my crew.
8. What are your starship combat experiences that do not include Accord-issues
missions, organised decoy beacons, or simulators?
You entered: I have fought against Lambda Pirate Cartel, Omega Pirate Cartel,
allied pirate / merry band and unreg ships during salvage ops and minor
skirmishes.
9. What would you say is your greatest weakness as a combat pilot?
You entered: When I am solo, I often do not begin repairs as soon as I should.
10. How long do you expect this ship to remain undamaged?
You entered: `Well, since I tend to get hit at least once during a beacon or 
combat situation, not long. I plan to conduct a beacon drop as soon as I can
after purchasing and upgrading it.
11. How would you predict this ship will be destroyed?
You entered: Perhaps during an invasion or minor skirmisPerhaps during an
invasion or if I attempt a very high decoy beacon drop in it, but hopefully, it
will never be destroyed.
12. What do you plan to name this ship, should you acquire one?
You entered: Lethal Strike
13. You must choose a theme song that you will completely rock out to while
fighting. What song do you choose?
You entered: Thunderstruck by ACDC
14. What is your favorite color?
You entered: Red
l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a dark green
leather captain's chair here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
out
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Airlock]
You can go out and enter into the ship.
out
You exit the ship.
[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
You can go up.
u

here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.

1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
You entered: I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy
any interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many
ships as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be
reinforced and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My
goal would be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
You entered: I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and
request reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be
placed on stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the
way, I would engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy
any interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of
the enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance
space from all hostile threats.
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
You entered: I attempt to destroy any chaining ships, interdicting ships and any
interdictors in the sector all the while staying close to the edge in order to
make a quick get away. Having taken note of the number of ships remaining in the
sector, I leave, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to determine the
number of the reinforcing ships. I report all of this over tactical and ask for
reinforcements.

cannot be destroyed by conventional weapons. The last magistrate-class
mothership had to be captured with the use of battle suits. We contact the
Accord and don't come back without cruisers that have been adapted with special
shielding that can repel a PDB and battle suits.

inhabited and also the primary beacon sectors since they are used the most and
one must fly through those sectors to get to capitol sectors. If, for example,
providence Gate were to be interdicted, other ships would not be able to get to

launch

power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
ftl telex
The ship is already moving.
ftl telex

proceed to Telex in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order is
entered."

Welcome to home space!"

write application
You scan the questions written on a starship requisition application and begin
filling them out.
(15 seconds roundtime.)
1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy any
interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many ships
as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be reinforced
and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My goal would
be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
You entered: I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy
any interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many
ships as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be
reinforced and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My
goal would be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and request
reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be placed on
stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the way, I would
engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy any
interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of the
enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance space
from all hostile threats.
You entered: I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and
request reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be
placed on stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the
way, I would engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy
any interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of
the enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance
space from all hostile threats.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']
y
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "Someone with red should GMG
with me."
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "Just saying."
[General Communication] Morris Corlew transmits, "I would, but I'm already here.
How bout Ted?"
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I don't have that long today."
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "How long is not that long."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I could do a few sites maybe."
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "Sure, I'm not going to be
picky."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Need to be back here in less
than 4 hours."
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "Sure thing."
[General Communication] Erik Goodwin transmits, "What you want me in?"
I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily on lasers
that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is able to
recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is depleted, the
ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of being short a
gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can move to the
empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons room's grid is
recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer to apply quick
patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a failsafe or not.
Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can increase the damage
for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for being short a gunner.
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if
appropriate, and is properly spellchecked! [Enter `yes' or `no']

back without cruisers that have been adapted with special shielding that can

1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
You entered: I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy
any interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many
ships as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be
reinforced and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My
goal would be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
You entered: I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and
request reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be
placed on stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the
way, I would engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy
any interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of
the enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance
space from all hostile threats.
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
You entered: I attempt to destroy any chaining ships, interdicting ships and any
interdictors in the sector all the while staying close to the edge in order to
make a quick get away. Having taken note of the number of ships remaining in the
sector, I leave, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to determine the
number of the reinforcing ships. I report all of this over tactical and ask for
reinforcements.

[Telex-Providence Spaceport; Metro Rail Station]
Though encroached upon by gigantic flora from all sides, this railway platform
is fully functional and shinily modern. Gleaming tracks lead away to the west,
weaving through towering trees toward the City of Providence--though you can't
see it from here thanks to the oppressive foliage. Digital readouts discreetly
placed above the platform provide arrival and departure times, updated by the
minute. Through an automatic sliding door to the north, you can see the bustle
of the spaceport's central hall. A prominently placed sign indicates that this
stop on the metro rail circuit is currently closed for maintenance.

that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is able to
recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is depleted, the
ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of being short a
gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can move to the
empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons room's grid is
recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer to apply quick
patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a failsafe or not.
Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can increase the damage
for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for being short a gunner.
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
Is this okay? Please make sure that your answer is a complete sentence, if

4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
I attempt to destroy any chaining ships, interdicting ships and any interdictors
in the sector all the while staying close to the edge in order to make a quick
get away. Having taken note of the number of ships remaining in the sector, I
leave, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to determine the number of the
reinforcing ships. I report all of this over tactical and ask for
reinforcements.

be captured with the use of battle suits. We contact the Accord and don't come
back without cruisers that have been adapted with special shielding that can
repel a PDB and battle suits.

6. In the event of a large-scale invasion of human space by hostile forces, what
would be your priority and why?
My priority would be the capitol planets as they are the most inhabited and also
the primary beacon sectors since they are used the most and one must fly through
those sectors to get to capitol sectors. If, for example, providence Gate were
to be interdicted, other ships would not be able to get to New Earth until such
time that Providence Gate was no longer interdicted.

1. You encounter a hostile force in deep space that clearly outmatches your own.
What do you do and why?
You entered: I engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships and then destroy
any interdictors that are in the sector. I then would try to destroy as many
ships as possible before I leave. If left alone, the hostile force could be
reinforced and eventually find its way to a civilian location and attack it. My
goal would be to try to cripple it as much as possible and still save my ship.
2. Consider the above question again, but now assume that the overwhelming
hostile force is threatening a civilian location. What do you do and why?
You entered: I would report my location, number and class of enemy ships and
request reinforcements over tactical. I would also recommend that a crew be
placed on stand-by at the civilian location. While reinforcements are on the
way, I would engage any chaining ships, interdicting ships as well as destroy
any interdictors in the sector. Then I would simply attempt to destroy all of
the enemy ships. It is my duty and responsibility to protect human alliance
space from all hostile threats.
3. Would you rather be short one gunner or short an engineer? Why?
You entered: I would much rather be short one gunner. As AEU ships rely heavily
on lasers that drain the grid rather quickly, it is imperative that someone is
able to recharge the grid as frequently as possible. If the combat grid is
depleted, the ship's weapons lose their effectiveness. Another advantage of
being short a gunner is that if a gunner's combat grid is drained, he or she can
move to the empty weapons room until such time that their original weapons
room's grid is recharged. If the ship does get hit, the ability of the engineer
to apply quick patches to the hull can be the difference between losing a
failsafe or not. Experienced engineers also can have access to tools that can
increase the damage for a single weapon room thereby helping to compensate for
being short a gunner.
4. Your ship has one failsafe left and enemy reinforcements will be arriving
soon. What actions do you take?
You entered: I attempt to destroy any chaining ships, interdicting ships and any
interdictors in the sector all the while staying close to the edge in order to
make a quick get away. Having taken note of the number of ships remaining in the
sector, I leave, obtain repairs, and use long-range scans to determine the
number of the reinforcing ships. I report all of this over tactical and ask for
reinforcements.
5. You are part of a large combat force attacking an Outsider patrol. You easily
overwhelm them, but before you can take out the stragglers, a Magistrate-class
regional mothership appears. What do you and your allies do and why?
You entered: We destroy the escorting ships and leave since this kind of ship
cannot be destroyed by conventional weapons. The last magistrate-class
mothership had to be captured with the use of battle suits. We contact the
Accord and don't come back without cruisers that have been adapted with special
shielding that can repel a PDB and battle suits.
6. In the event of a large-scale invasion of human space by hostile forces, what
would be your priority and why?
You entered: My priority would be the capitol planets as they are the most
inhabited and also the primary beacon sectors since they are used the most and
one must fly through those sectors to get to capitol sectors. If, for example,
providence Gate were to be interdicted, other ships would not be able to get to
New Earth until such time that Providence Gate was no longer interdicted. 
7. In an emergency, you and your ship are placed at the disposal of a naval wing
commander. How do you feel you would handle this situation?
You entered: I would simply obey the naval wing commander within reason,
ensuring first that I understood everything he or she asked of me and my crew.

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at Telex-Providence Spaceport; Landing Pad.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a dark green
leather captain's chair here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
out
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Airlock]
You can go out and enter into the ship.

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a dark green
leather captain's chair here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
ftl new
The ship is already moving.
ftl new
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Deadly
Strike! Welcome to home space!"

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a dark green
leather captain's chair here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on a dark green leather captain's chair.)

a wormhole drive tracer

You see a swiveling dark green leather gunner's chair and an improved temporary
wormhole drive here.
You can go west.

launch

launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."
